huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Monroe is a popular unit for hunting and outdoor recreation. There is ample public land with good road/trail access. Valley floors start between 5,000 – 6,000 feet with some of the peaks reaching near 11,000 ft in elevation. Habitat types include sagebrush, pinyon/juniper woodlands, and aspen/conifer.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for snow, rain, lightning, cold and high temperatures.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions.  During some seasons very warm temperatures may occur. Hunters should be prepared to cool meat quickly to avoid wasting meat.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~1000 - 1400~1100~~~6.5–7.0~7.4~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
General Considerations: The Monroe unit has long been considered a great unit to hunt elk. Good numbers of Mature bulls, beautiful scenery, and good access makes it a popular place to hunt. It is managed for an average age of harvested bull of 6.5-7yrs.

Early Any Weapon season: Elk use the entire Monroe unit. During the Early Any Weapon season the rut is in full swing. Bulls are usually very vocal, especially early in the morning. By this time, due to the rut and hunting pressure, some of the elk have started using the mid elevation oak and pinyon/juniper habitats. Most of the bulls are with or at least near the cow herds. A good number of elk have also began to move south on the unit. The southern part of the unit will have increased numbers of elk during this season. Warm temperatures common during this time of year sometimes keep elk in the cooler canyon.

Generally there are no other hunts during this season. As a result, hunters enjoy a quality hunt with little pressure from other hunters.

Good areas to hunt: The central part of the unit is the most popular place for elk hunters for several reasons: There is really good camping and access, the terrain is mild, and the largest part of the elk herd resides there during the archery hunt. Elk can be found across the entire central part of the unit. Just about every meadow and canyon may have elk in them. Many people hunt this large area consisting of gentle terrain between the Dry Creek ranger station and the Koosharem ranger station. There are several large tracts of private property here. Consult maps to avoid conflicts with Private ground.

Hunters should not overlook the many side canyons that lead from the top of the plateau down to the foothills. Elk use these because of the good feed and also they get less pressure as there are fewer roads. During this season there are generally significant numbers of elk using the agricultural fields near Koosharem, Greenwich, and Monroe. If you ask, many of these landowners may grant permission to hunt on their property or at least pass through. Generally the elk move onto public ground during daylight hours so they are accessible.

Good numbers of elk also use the north end of the mountain. Elk can be found near Hunter’s Flat, Big Lake, Magleby pass, and Monument peak. There are several sections of private ground in this area so be sure to know where you are. Make sure to check the mid-elevation areas.

A few elk have now moved down to the south end of the unit during this hunt. Elk will be on the Forshea Mountain area where the thick aspen stands are. There are also small groups of elk stretching from the Forshea to the Langdon mountain area.

Migration Patterns: Though most of the elk that spend the summer on Monroe also stay there for the winter. A significant number also migrate south to the Mt. Dutton unit. This movement usually begins in September and elk trickle south through November. Because of this, do not count on bulls being is the same place you may have scouted them in during the summer. Also, many elk now use the mid-elevation areas that have fewer roads and less pressure.

Scouting Tips: June is a great time to begin scouting, as elk are less wary and there will be less people on the mountain. Elk will still be growing their antlers but will be easier to locate. The elk may move before this hunt but you will have an idea of what is in the area. A scouting trip just before the season opens will tell you what areas the bulls and cow herds are using. A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for effective and efficient scouting in this area.

Other Information: Hunters enjoy a high harvest rate on the Monroe unit. Hunters are usually able to locate quite a few mature bulls during scouting and hunting trips. This unit typically produces good mature bulls though not as many really large bulls as some nearby units that have more difficult terrain and access.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  Public lands include lands managed by the BLM, USFS (Fish Lake National Forest), and the state of Utah.  Most of the mountainous ground is public land and open to the public. There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low country and high country. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Elbow Ranch WMA - The Elbow Ranch WMA is a large winter range area. Do not expect high numbers of big game or bears to use this area during most hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is only one official campground located on the unit. This campground is owned by the Koosharem Band of Piutes and is located adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Hotel/camping accommodations exist in cities and towns that surround the unit. There is also a nearby campground at Otter Creek State Park. Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most public ground. Please direct camping questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fishlake National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are several main access roads to the Monroe unit. You can access the north side via road #068 from either the town of Annabella or Glenwood. This is a well maintained gravel road. From the east side you can take road #076 out of Koosharem and #069 out of Greenwich. Road #069 is the best road to take if you are pulling camp a trailer. The south end of the mountain can be accessed with the Pole canyon road (#072) near Angle or the Monroe Mountain road (#068) near Kingston. Both of these are maintained but are rather narrow and not recommended for large trailers. To access the west side of the unit use the Dry Creek road (#071) or the Monroe Canyon road (#078). Both of these roads are not recommended for trailers.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina.  USFS Travel Management map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV and Vehicle Access: The Monroe unit has an extensive road and trail system. Many good areas to hunt can be accessed via vehicle. During the early hunting seasons most all roads and trails can be accessed. During later seasons early and heavy snows may make travel difficult. Some trails are restricted to ATVs of a certain size only. Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low elevation and high areas. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Please respect all private lands and associated trespass laws.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Piute and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and I-70 near Sevier; south on US-89 to SR-62; east and north on SR-62 to SR-24; north on SR-24 to I-70; south on I-70 to US-89 near Sevier. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.
